Don Haskins! Come on. Dance with me. LATER ON THE DANCE FLOOR... Haskins and Mary dance togeth
(heavy Oklahoma drawl) I’m sure havin’ a good time, Mary.
Me, too, Don.
Did I tell you I got accepted to A&M?
Just about ten times tonight.
Guess I’m just excited.
Oh, it‘ll be nice for you. Goin’ off to college. Much as you love to play basketball. Sometimes I think there’s nothing you love more...

No, Mary, I-- I love you... too... Fact is, there’s somethin’ I’m wantin’ to ask a long time now-- and I don't always say things right-- but Mary, you're my girl. I want to spend my life with you-- Will you marry me?

(a slow beaming smile) Guess I'll take second place-- for now. He picks her up and twirls her in the air on the dance fl EXT. ENID FEED AND GRAIN - LOADING AREA — NEXT DAY Haskins and Carr play basketball behind the store.
Brother, you fall hard. But-- Mary’s a nice girl. She'll make you a good wife.
Yeah. Yeah. Come on. Last point. Carr lifts off with breathtaking agility. The BALL floats through the net. Haskins groans. Carr grins back.
You hate to lose, man.
I don’t hate to lose, I just like to win. My Daddy always drummed it into me. ‘You play to win’.
(looks at basket; thoughtful) You ever get that feeling when you're playing?-- That feeling like you're moving like Sam Cooke sings. Sounds funny, but when I play-- I feel like that.
Sam Cooke? Is he from Enid?
Brother, you one Okie.
Well, make fun, but I ain't never felt like that. But I reckon’ I don't play like you neither. (MORE)
HASKINS (cont'd) I sure’ll be glad when I can play with you not against your skinny butt. Did you get your letter yet from A&M? CARR. We ain’t gonna be playin’ together.
What do you mean?
I got my letter. They don't play black folk. Told me to stay home and work my job.
They can’t do that! You’re the best player in the state!
Guess that don’t matter.
Well-- if you ain’t goin’ neither am I!
Stop talkin’ like a fool, man! Playin’ basketball's your life. You better be goin’! At least-- at least one of us--...
(pained for him) What are you gonna do now, Herman?
I’1l be alright. You know. That's just how it goes. Wasn't my time.
But it just ain’t right. Wish there was somethin’ I could do.
Play for me, Don. You make it big, alright? You go all the way, Don. Don nods. Carr pulls him in, emotional. They embrace.

I better go now. Carr nods, tight. Don turns to his car. He gets in and st the engine. Carr comes out as Don pulls away. Don looks i the mirror and sees Carr on the sidewalk, broom in hand, to the "Whites Only" drinking fountain.

Don drives to BUCK OWENS and ROSE MADDOX'S "Mental Cruelt Mary holds a NEW BABY in her arms. Their FIRST SON bounce the back as they pass a sign: "BENJAMIN, TEXAS. POP 250."
It'll be great, honey! I'll coach. We'll have a house with a yard for the kids! They'll even let me drive the bus to make ends meet! Honey, it'll be paradise!
Haskins exhorts the BENJAMIN GIRL'S TEAM playing the DEFE STATE CHAMPS. The clock runs down as the crowd, cheers.

Winnaker! Get on Robinson! Play the ball! What are you doin' out there! You're not stickin' to your man. What are you, a bunch of girls? Come on, hustle! IN THE CROWD. GEORGE MCCARTY, a COLLEGIATE ATHLETIC DIREC sits watching Haskins with interest. The BUZZER SOUNDS. The girls leap in the air. Swarming ar Haskins, they try to LIFT the big man on their shoulders, quickly collapse under his weight.
TROPHIES LINE A SHELF. Don watches TV. On screen is a NCA GAME: ADOLPH RUPP, the legendary coach of the “Kentucky Wildcats”, plays an arena full of screaming fans.

The ‘Baron of the Bluegrass‘, Adolph Rupp, does it again! Winning the Southern Conference berth and returning to the NCAA Tournament for the thirtieth time. The question now is: can Rupp, the greatest coach in the game, win an unprecedented fifth National Championship? Haskins flicks off the TV, moody as Mary enters.  HASKINS. There's gotta be more than this, Mary. More than Benjamin, Texas.
Always restless. Always gotta have better. You got a family now. You’re a winning coach. Is that so bad?
ON THE TELEVISION we see young BILL COSBY and ROBERT CULP gun toting partners in the “I Spy” series. THROUGH THE WI OUTSIDE... Don is coaching his three year old son, MARK.
Come on! I pass, you catch and put it up! Don zips a ridiculous pass at Mark. It bounces off his ch

Catch it with your hands-- not your arms! Mark's lips quiver and he cries. Haskins tries to console as Mary comes and takes him, flashing a look. Haskins goe and stops at the TV as the old crank PHONE on the wall RI He picks up as we hear a VOICE.
This is Dr. Ray at Texas Western University. We'd like to speak to you about an opportunity.
DR. RAY, college president, sits with George McCarty, the University’s Athletic Director, facing a neatly combed Ha

I’m pleased to hear you're interested in the coaching job, Mr. Haskins. The Texas Athletic Association recommended we take a look at you. McCarty here caught your last championship game. He says you’re a winner.
Yes, sir. I sure ‘preciate that.
We're a small school and we can’t pay very much. You'd have to live in the men's dorm with your family. But you get free meals at the cafeteria. How’s that sound?
If that’s what it takes to coach Division One basketball, that’s alright with me.

(shaking his hand; smile) Welcome to Texas Western. INT. DON’S BUICK - MOVING ~ TEXAS INTERSTATE - DAY Mary holds a NEW BABY. TWO SONS in back. They tow a cattl truck of their belongings to MARTY ROBBINS’ "El Paso". Th town sprawls out in the middle of vast, desolate nothingn

Baby, this is a step up. It’s college basketball! We’re in the big time now. EXT. TEXAS WESTERN CAMPUS - OUTSIDE MINERS DORMS -— DAY Families drop off their kids with suitcases and hugs and tears as Don's Buick pulls up. Haskins gets out. A dark haired boy, JERRY ARMSTRONG, stands with his FATHER, a ha farming type.
How long you gonna waste your time, boy? Playin’ a kids game when you got your whole future right there on the farn.
I made up my mind, Pa. It’s what I wanna do. Don notes it and walks ahead when he hears a WHISTLE and Mary is surrounded by kids and suitcases. He turns, sheep
Sorry, baby. Guess I’m just excited.
ROWDY STUDENTS run past. Don walks with MOE “SQUEAKY” IBA a very short, earnest ASSISTANT COACH with horn-rimmed gl His voice is high, hence the unfortunate nickname.

We're clearing out our best rooms for you, Mr. Haskins. I think you and your family are gonna like it. He opens a door to a room full of taxidermy and fishing g An alligator hangs from the ceiling. ROSS MOORE, TEAM TRAINER, 65, stands in his underwear: a grinning Cajun with crew cut.
This is Ross Moore. Our team trainer. He's movin’ to a smaller room down the hall.
I hate to put you out--
Don't you worry a thing. I'm even willing to lend you my prize gator here. Makes a real nice ceiling ornament.
(eyeing the snarling gator) That's real kind of you, Ross. But the wife doesn’t take to wildlife too much. But I thank you. I do.
Mary stands with her baby as GUADALUPE, a domestic from Juarez, is warming milk, smiling at the baby.

Que carinfo. Can I hold him? Guadalupe radiates so much warmth, that Mary hands her th baby. Guadalupe coos with the boy. Mary smiles, happy. INT. “MEMORIAL GYM” - TEXAS WESTERN - NEXT DAY Moe walks with Don into Memorial Gym. A bunch of short, s white guys pass the ball around.

Got some good players. Signed Baudoin outta Albuquerque. Put up twenty a game last year. Got us a strong farm boy outta Missouri, too. Kid named Armstrong. The gym has worn seats, loose boards, crooked rims, threa nets. Lights buzz and flicker. Hardly a place of champion
David Palacio’s top prep scorer in El Paso. Still waitin’ on some junior college transfers. And on Taco Night-- we get a real good crowd.
Taco night? My girls had better moves than these kids. What's in the budget for recruiting?
The budget’s in the lights.
Don stands across from McCarty, the Athletic Director. INT/EXT.
How in Sam-hell can I put a winning team on the floor when I got no players and no budget to get them?
I could shake down a few more bucks from the boosters. Get a couple scholarships.
A few bucks?! I can’t go recruit with one or two scholarships.

Don, you know damn well we ain't Kansas, Duke, Kentucky. We’re a poor school. We can't afford blue chip players, and they wouldn't want to play in this dusty-ass town even if we could. Reality is, we're lucky to put a decent team on the court.
Well, decent ain’t good enough for me. I play to win.
Don drives by the Rio Grande; through night time streets; the top of Mt. Franklin; staring out, discontent.
Don stands by his car in a jacket with “Miners” logo. TWO WHITE and HISPANIC, look at him from their pick-up truck.
Hey, you’re the new coach. Gonna get us some wins this year?
I’1l do my best.

Good luck, man. You’re gonna need it. Don nods, depressed. They laugh and drive off. EXT. DON’S BUICK ~- DRIVING - EL PASO - LATER THAT NIGHT Don stops as something catches his eye: A BLACK TEENAGER basketball court. Don watches the boy LIFT into the air a soar SKYWARD. We FLASH to the IMAGE OF HERMAN CARR cleari the rim. As Carr JAMS the ball into the hoop, Haskins wat the boy lay the ball off the board in a silky motion.
MARTIN LUTHER KING is seen on a TELEVISION, as he speaks RALLY IN D.C.. Haskins sits with Moe and Ross at a table.
You're beatin’ a dead horse, Coach. We're never gonna compete with the Kentucky’s of the world.
Best players won't even look at us.
Best white players, you mean.
Say that again, Sonny?
Best players aren’t all white. (looks around at them) What if we find us the best black talent in the country and bring 'em here?
You got to be joking. Why would you wanna go do a thing like that?
I don’t care what color anybody is, black, white, green. If they can play, they can play for me.
How many are you talkin’ about?
As many as we can get.  10.
Coach. There are rules. Unwritten rules. You know the quotas. ‘One at home. Two on the road. Three when you're losing.’ But loading up on Negroes-- it just isn't done.
Who cares about rules? Rules are meant to be broken.
Now you listen, Sonny. You bring in a bunch of colored boys-- you risk the whole program.
I’m not afraid of risks. I’m not afraid to gamble. Not if it means winning.

CLOSE UP: BOBBY JOE HILL, a black kid from Detroit with a fancy conk, leans back on a sideline bench in the middle noisy Junior College Nationals game, DOZING, HALF~ASLEEP. ON THE FLOOR... all the PLAYERS are white. They play supe conservative, pass and set-shot ball of the day. IN THE STANDS... Don sits with Moe and Ross.
Three days, nine games, and you ain’t liked nobody yet.
I’m waitin’ on that guard.
That kid? He looks asleep!

‘Cause nobody’s playin’ him. ON COURT... the team is being destroyed. The COACH gruffl shakes Bobby Joe awake and signals him into the game. Bobby Joe, once awake, has intelligent, playful eyes and cocky demeanor. He quickly takes the court. Immediately t game changes. Lightning quick, he finds openings where th aren't any, dribbles past players with dazzling speed.
That's the one. Let’s us go talk to him.  ll.
Haskins stands with a beer-belly Redneck TOURNAMENT DIREC

You wanna talk to Bobby Joe Hill? You can't win playin' ‘nigger ball. Can't control ‘em. Sure they can jump like goddamn monkeys. But they can’t lead. That boy in particular. He’s just a no- account smart ass. Showboatin' like a globetrotter clown.
Just tell me where to find him.
Y'all must be real hard up.
Bobby Joe Hill is clearing his locker. Don walks up with and Ross. Bobby Joe sees them, wary.
I’m Coach Haskins. I wanna talk to you about playing for me at Texas Western.
Thanks but-- I’m done playin’ this game.
I’m offerin’ a full scholarship.
I know how that works. You sign me and sit your token Negro on the bench. I'd rather hang it up, do somethin’ else. Ace. Be the next Smokey Robinson. Or I could run for president.
I watched you out there. You got somethin’ special. Why would you throw it away?
Because ever since I was a kid I only loved one thing and that was playin’ ball. (MORE)

BOBBY JOE (cont'd) But being a black mascot, ridin’ the bench like some Stepin’ Fetchit ass lawn jockey while White brothers with half my game get the glory may be good enough for most brothers, but not for Bobby Joe Hill, not anymore. I‘1l walk away from the game rather than play that shit. He grabs his duffle bag and walks out of the locker room.
Haskins follows Hill, trying to keep up.
I didn’t come here to sit you on the bench. I intend to let you play. Play with other black men.
What are you smokin’, Jack?
I ain’t smokin’ nuthin’, Bubba. Now you just told me about a big ol’ dream you have. I can let you play, and I can help you make that dream come true faster than a twister’ll take your socks off.
You know, you talk funny.
So do you.
What’s this team anyway?
The Miners.
I never even heard of them. They any good?
You can help make them good.
Are you for real, man?

(holding up the papers) Try me.  13. EXT. DON’S BUICK - DRIVING TENNESSEE FREEWAY - DUSK A long stretch of highway in the setting sun. Don‘s Buick seen from way on high OVER BOBBY FULLER'S “I Fought The L
MUSIC CONTINUES on JUKE BOX. Ross on a pay phone. Don wat GOOD 01’ BOYS shoot pool. Moe flips through scouting repo

Okay. According to the scouts, here’s who we need to see. Harry Flournoy. Indiana. Great rebounder in high school. Gave it up to work in the steel mills. Orsten “Little O” Artis. Can shoot the lights out. Lot of schools want him. David Lattin. He’s a long shot. Down in Houston. They say he’s a hot head, but he’s one of the top big men in the country. Everybody says he’s leaning to Tennessee A@I, the all black school.
We'll get him. We have to get him.
And how we gonna do that? We ain’t even got enough gas money to get home. Ross hangs up the phone and sits down, excited.
I got through to Hilton White in New York. He’s got three kids we should look at. Now they’re just playground kids, but Hilton knows talent and he says they can play with anybody.
Moe, you're on the first flight out.
You’re sendin’ me to New York for some school yard players?! Who’s payin’ for all this? You gotta be outta your mind.
Bubba, I’m just gettin’ started. Haskins grabs a pool cue and puts a quarter on the pool t  14.
Ya'll mind if I give it a run, fellas? GOOD OL’ BOY We play for real money here, Mister.
The good ol’ boy lays a C-NOTE down, grinning. Ross and M watch Haskins empties his pockets to the last quarter.
What the hell you doin’, Coach?

Just layin’ down the corn... The good ol’ boy sinks quick shots, rimming out of the co pocket. Then Haskins runs the table, down to the eight ba The good ol’ boy’s speechless. Haskins takes the C Note.

There's one rule in pool, boys. Don’t play with amputees or strangers. (tossing the money) Here’s your plane fare, Squeaky. INT. DON’S BUICK - DRIVING ON FREEWAY - DAY Don and Ross driving. Ross sings to BIG BILL LISTER “Ther A Tear In My Beer” at the top of his voice, annoying Hask

Haskins and Ross in the car, watch TWO BLACK WORKERS from mill, play one-on-one on concrete with a hoop and no net. HARRY FLOURNOY, tall, powerful, slams in a basket-rattlin two. His FRIEND grins, shaking his head. They rap hands.
You comin’ over? I got the new Otis Redding. That cat’s on fire, man.
Dig, man, but I can’t stay long. Mama baked some pie. There's only one piece left and I been thinking about it all day.
Hey, kid-- you have a minute? Don pulls up, COUNTRY MUSIC blaring.  15.
We don’t want no trouble, Mister.
No, you don't understand, just get in the car and we can--
Like hell, I’m gettin’ in no car with a couple’a crackers! Haskins stops the car. Flournoy looks at his friend. On c they both run. Haskins watches them, and drives ahead.
Harry enters through the back door and flings his factory down. His MOTHER carries a tray of coffee to the next roo

Hey, Ma. You won't believe happened to me and Alvin. Almost got jumped by a couple of red-necked crackers. (looking around) I'm just dying for that piece of pie. Mrs. Flournoy enters the living room with Flournoy follow He stops, shocked, when he sees HASKINS sitting at a tabl next to Flournoy's FATHER, eating his PIECE OF BLUEBERRY
Ma‘am, this is plumb delicious-- Mrs. Flournoy pushes her speechless son into a chair.
This is Mr. Haskins. He come all the way from El Paso, Texas. Wants you to play basketball for him on a scholarship!
Play for him? Why would I go to Texas where they soon as string up black men as set off Fourth of July fireworks? FLOURNOY’S FATHER Harry's got a good job right here in Gary. At the factory. With me.
But he can get himself an education.  16.
And a Texas-sized beating for being black.
El Paso’s not like the rest of Texas. We do things different. You'll be playing with other black players.
Why should I trust you?
‘Cause I mean what I say. There is a tense silence. Flournoy glares at Haskins.
You ate my pie. Haskins leans in close.
Harry, forget about me or your parents. What is it that you really want?
What anybody wants. Dignity. Respect.
That's what this is all about. You can earn that for yourself by doing what you were born to do. Haskins slides the commitment papers across the table.
Papa?
They're right, Harry. You have a chance to follow your dream. Don’t let it go. Flournoy looks at his father with emotion and signs the p
Haskins’ car pulls up in front of the YMCA and parks.
ORSTEN ARTIS, a good looking player, with a smooth, easy sinks a shot with A BEVY OF GIRLS swooning. Haskins besid  17.
I got lots of offers. But I just made up my mind to play with the Globetrotters.
And act the fool with your talent? What I‘m offering you is better. I can make you a champion.
Is this a joke?
I never joke about winning. Haskins lays a letter of intent on the free throw line.
Tell you what. I’m not really a gamblin’ man, but-- how ‘bout we shoot for it. Best of twenty. You win and I'm outta here. I win-- you play for me.
You want to take me on?!
That's the general idea.
Let’s do it. Orsten shoots as his friends count along. He misses THE L SHOT and tosses the ball to Haskins, cocky.
It's all yours, cowboy. Haskins first shot rims and drops in. Orsten and friends expressions change as Haskins drills shot after shot. Orsten’s mouth is agape as the last shot slithers through
Don's Buick barrels into frame and disappears down the highway. We hear TAMMY WYNETTE’S “My Elusive Dreams”.
Moe stands at a phone booth, while THREE BLACK PLAYERS bl past in the background, shooting baskets with amazing ski  18.

These New York kids may be from the street but they sure can play! Little guard plays like he's a giant. Forward who runs like an antelope. A swing man who can play anywhere! Never seen anything like ‘em!
When can you have them out?
Week maybe. How’s it going with Lattin? We got to have a big man.
Don stands, one hand covering his ear from traffic noise.
The odds are long, but I got one more roll in these dice.
Haskins sits with A&I’s BLACK COACH. Beside him is DAVID huge, powerful, with shaved head and intimidating self~as

David, this is a good school and they give lots of players a chance they wouldn’t get somewhere else. But it’s still just the black league. You’re not out there being tested in the real world. David, the way you play, you could be the next Bill Russell. But you'll never know unless you play NCAA competition and win. And frankly that means playing the best white centers in the country and beating them.
I can beat any honky ass white boy. Big Daddy D can play with anyone.
Then prove it. Sign with me.
How's he gonna play anybody at all at Texas Western? A red neck town with a team that’s never won? We know that game. You’1l take David and make him ride the bench like any plantation nigger.  19.
You think I could be the next Bill Russell?
You play for me and I promise you'll get that chance.
(looking torn) You're too late. I already made up my mind. I'm signing with Tennessee. The coach smiles at Haskins, smug. Haskins finally nods.
So that's how it is, huh? You’re better than this, David. You change your mind, you call me, you hear? Just call.
Ross drives the NEW YORK PLAYERS and Moe. WILLIE WORSLEY, short, urbanite, militant, with a “Napoleon complex” sits next to Moe who is eyeing Worsley’s HIGH HEELED BOOTS.
What you lookin’ at? I sky with anyone.

I know that, Willie. IN THE BACK ROW is WILLIE “SCOOPS” CAGER, a lanky player a cocky attitude and a good heart. His childhood friend a protege, NEVIL SHED, a tall, skinny “mama's boy” beside h They pass tumbleweeds and the waterless Rio Grande.
This don’t exactly look like them Lone Ranger movies. You know, with them rollin’ hills and big ass prairies.
Where the hell's this Coach bringin’ us?
El Paso, Texas. God’s country.
If this is God’s country, good Lord must be mad at somethin’.  20.

There ain't no place like El Paso. Beautiful West Texas sunlight three hundred and thirty days a year. It’s ‘bout heaven on earth. They almost believe him. Then a pick-up truck full of ROO swerves ahead. Chickens fly over the van as Ross curses something Cajun. The players are jolted back to reality.

FIVE WHITE PLAYERS look into the cafeteria through a wind the door: JERRY ARMSTRONG, the farm boy we saw with his f DICK MYERS, a tall, clean cut Kansan, DAVID PALACIO, a to proud Hispanic with a gold cross around his neck, LOUIS “ BAUDOIN, a prankster with buzz cut and horn rimmed glasse TOGO RAILEY, a skinny kid who brings more enthusiasm than
Well, look who's just come to dinner.
Those our new team mates?
There’s more blacks than us whites! How’s he gonna play all them players?
You think Coach knows what he’s doing?
He said things were gonna be different this year. Guess he wasn’t kidding.
Nevil Shed waits in line, towering over Willie Worsley.

Don’t that smell good? I can't wait to eat me a whole tray full of food. This big ol’ boy's starvin'! MEANWHILE... THE BLACK RECRUITS sit at one end of a table while the WHITE PLAYERS sit at the other end. They nod a silent greeting. There is an awkward silence and tense sm
Where you brothers from, man?  21.
Missoura. Dick here's from Kansas.
Wow. So you guys had cows, chickens and pigs and stuff?
Armstrong's the farm boy. We just had some sheep, that’s all.
You got animals where you come from?
In New York City they got all kinda animals. Most of them talk though. CAFETERIA LINE... Shed looks at the Mexican dishes, confu
You said it was-- what?!
Menudo. Muy bueno.
I never even heard of that. AT THE TABLE... Togo smiles at the wary Flournoy.
So-- you from Harlem or whatever?
You think all blacks are from Harlem?!
Take it easy, cabron. He didn’t mean nothing.
Yeah? And so where you from?
From right here. El Paso, Texas.
Really? I thought all you people were from Mexico.
Peace, man. Brothers, peace.  22.
I'm from New Mexico. That‘’s not even considered America. He smiles. Flournoy doesn't smile back. CAFETERIA LINE... The server hands Shed a plate of enchil
Rojo es bueno, si. Muy caliente.
(enunciating clearly) Thank you. Thank you very much. AT THE TABLE... Shed drops his tray down, rubbing his han

This Negro is ready to eat ala Mexicana! Shed scoops a mouthful of chile smothered enchilada. Bloo runs from his face. He lets out an 'I'm on fire' SCREAM a douses his mouth in water as the others laugh.
Don studies diagrams in playbooks as his sons, Mark and Michael clumsily demonstrate juggling tricks with oranges
Look, Daddy, look, look, Daddy, look!
Go on, boys. Time for bed. Daddy's got work to do. The boys walk out, heads hanging. Just then loud MUSIC ri from the street. Haskins looks out, puzzled.

The wheels of a green Plymouth Fury convertible roll into frame. As the car approaches, a crowd forms around it. IN THE BACKSEAT there are speakers wired to the stereo wi THE ROLLING STONES “Get Off Of My Cloud” playing. THE CAR stops. Door opens and a pair of WHITE SHOES steps Cager, Worsley, and Orsten come to the front, gaping.
Qooh, Mama, look at them wheels!  23.
That brother is stylin'. ANGLE ON: DAVID LATTIN with shaved head, green silk shirt Ray Bans, looking around.
That is one bad ass car.
That is one bad ass man. Haskins comes walking outside, looking speechless.
David?... What happened?
I'm the best. I came to be the best. Haskins looks back at him a moment. He slowly smiles.

Welcome to El Paso, David. They shake hands. The others gather and slap him on the b Worsley has his hand outheld for a shake. Lattin drops hi suitcase in Worsley’s hand and walks off. Worsley frowns.
Mercy Jesus, we in for trouble.
Ross leads some of the black players across campus.
Straight ahead is the gym, fellas. Shed and Cager follow. As they pass a MARIACHI BAND, practicing with guitars and violin. Shed looks at Cager.
Willie, we still in America?
Orsten and Worsley pass by friendly, smiling students in cowboy hats. They glance back at them, non-plussed.
Bobby Joe comes down as two GIRLS smile at him.
Groovy. You play for the Miners?
I didn’t know they played Negros.
If they don't, I took the wrong plane.
The black players are dressing. A HISPANIC JANITOR comes
You the new players?
The mighty Miners.
Mighty Miners?! This team ain’t had a winning season since Pearl Harbor! Mighty Miners. That’s funny. He walks out, chuckling. The players look at each other g
The players follow Ross into the rickety gym dressed in g Russell t-shirts with orange shorts. They look around.
This is it. This is the place. Your new home. You boys have no idea kinda things gonna happen around here.
That’s what I’m worried about, bro. Ross opens the door of COACH’S OFFICE. The players look i and see the trophies above Haskins’ desk, impressed.
We got lucky findin’ Coach Haskins. He won state last year, you know.
Yeah, man? No kidding.
Had those gals playin’ so tough, nobody could stop ‘em.  The players stare at the photos next to the trophies. each, Don stands smiling with the “Benjamin Eight” gi
You tellin’ us the man coached a girls team? A high school girls team?!
You bet. He’s a winner. The players look at each other, bleak.
